Directions
Thoroughly wash 6 (1/2-pint-size) canning jars and their lids. If you plan to process the jelly for shelf-stable storage, sterilize the jars as described in our
canning guide
.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
Coarsely chop 2 red bell peppers and 2 Fresno chiles, and place in bowl of a food processor. Pulse until very finely chopped, about 12 pulses, scraping down sides of bowl as needed. Transfer mixture to a large stockpot or Dutch oven. Using a knife, finely chop remaining 3 red bell peppers and the remaining Fresno chile; transfer to Dutch oven with peppers. Add green bell peppers, jalapeño chiles, and salt to Dutch oven.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
Cook, covered, over medium heat until peppers are completely softened, about 8 minutes.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
Uncover and simmer, stirring occasionally, until most of the liquid has evaporated, about 5 minutes. Stir in sugar and vinegar and bring mixture to a full boil over medium-high heat, then reduce to a simmer. Stir in pectin until dissolved, return heat to medium-high, and bring to a full rolling boil. As soon as mixture reaches a full boil, cook for 1 minute, then remove from heat. Let stand for 5 minutes. Using a metal spoon, carefully scrape any foam or scum from surface of jelly. Transfer jelly into prepared canning jars, leaving 1/4-inch space at the top. Using wet paper towels or a kitchen towel, wipe any jelly from the rims.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
For short-term storage:
Let jelly cool to room temperature, about 30 minutes. Screw on lids, and refrigerate until set, at least 12 hours. Jelly can be stored for up to 1 month in refrigerator. When ready to serve, stir jelly to distribute peppers evenly.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
For long-term storage:
While jelly is still hot, screw on tops until finger-tip tight (do not over-tighten). Place a canning rack in bottom of a large stockpot. Fill with water, and bring to a boil over high heat. Carefully lower jars into pot. Return water to boil over high; cover and boil for 10 minutes. Off-heat, let jars sit in water for 5 minutes. Using canning tongs, carefully remove jars from water. Jelly can be stored at room temperature for up to 1 year; refrigerate after opening and use within 3 weeks. When ready to serve, stir jelly to distribute peppers evenly.
Equipment
1/2-pint canning jars, lids, and rings, large stockpot or Dutch oven, deep stockpot (if canning), canning funnel (if canning), jar lifter (if canning)
Notes
This recipe was developed using low-sugar pectin; do not substitute other types of pectin unless you know how to properly adjust the recipe. We recommend using either the low-sugar pectin from Ball or brand or Sure-Jell rather than other brands (the brand Pomona's, in particular, did not work like Ball or Sure-Jell in our tests).
Jelly served cold will have a firmer texture. Bring to room temperature if a looser texture is desired.
Make-Ahead and Storage
Unprocessed jelly can be refrigerated for 1 month.
Processed (heat-treated) jelly can be stored in a cool, dark place for up to 1 year. After opening, refrigerate and use within 3 weeks.
When ready to serve, stir jelly to distribute peppers evenly.
